issues.description: Return-type mismatch for PersonService.addParent: The problem statement explicitly requires addParent to save the updated person and return the result (a Person). The template declares addParent with signature public Person addParent(Person person, Person parent) (returning Person). However, the solution implementation defines addParent as returning void. At the same time PersonResource (both in template and solution) calls person = personService.addParent(...), i.e., expects a returned Person. This creates an internal inconsistency in the solution (method returns void but callers expect a Person) and a cross-artifact inconsistency between problem statement/template and the solution. This will cause compile errors and/or confusion about the intended contract of addParent.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem statement and template by changing the solution's PersonService.addParent signature to return Person and return the saved entity. For example, change the method signature to public Person addParent(Person person, Person parent) { ...; return personRepository.save(person); }. This keeps PersonResource usage (person = personService.addParent(...)) valid and matches the exercise description.

issues.description: The problem statement and the template expect PersonService.addParent(Person person, Person parent) to return the saved Person (used by controllers/tests). The solution implementation defines addParent(...) with a void return type. This creates a semantic/API mismatch: controllers and tests in both template/solution invoke/assign the method's return value (e.g., person = personService.addParent(...); child = personService.addParent(...);), but the solution's service method does not return anything. Students will be confused which contract to implement and tests/controllers relying on a returned Person will not align with the solution's method signature.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the service signature consistent: change the solution's PersonService.addParent(Person person, Person parent) to return Person (the saved/updated person) and return personRepository.save(person). This aligns the service API with the problem statement, template controller usage, and tests. Alternatively, if void is intended, update the template/problem and all usages (controllers/tests) to not expect a return value — but returning the saved Person is the least disruptive and aligns with the stated requirements.
